docs.lead_paragraph: The recession has increased the nation's health care bills, forcing Americans to spend 5.7 percent more for health services and drugs in 2009 than they spent in 2008, according to new projections in a report by the federal Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services.

headline.main: Health Care's Share of U.S. Economy Rose at Record Rate

docs.abstract: Spending on health care represented 17.3 percent of G.D.P. in 2009, a record 1.1 percent increase over 2008.

docs.lead_paragraph: Most Americans think health care legislation is doomed, according to a survey released Wednesday by the Pew Research Center. But a growing, if still small, percentage of people are becoming more optimistic that it may pass. In the survey, conducted from Jan. 29 to Feb. 1, 60 percent of those polled said they thought health care legislation would not pass this year. That is fewer than the 67 percent who said just after a special Senate election last month in Massachusetts that health care would not pass.
docs.abstract: Survey released by Pew Research Center finds most Americans think health care legislation is doomed; growing, if still small, percentage are becoming more optimistic that it may pass; graph (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: For President Obama and Congressional Democrats groping for a new strategy on their stalled health care legislation, a crucial question is whether the way forward is to the right, to the left -- or would it be better to just stand still? Some Democratic advocacy groups, including the Progressive Change Campaign Committee and Democracy for America, insist that a main problem with the legislation is that it is not progressive enough.
docs.abstract: Democratic advocacy groups, including Progressive Change Campaign Committee and Democracy for America, insist main problem with health reform legislation is that it is not progressive enough; centrist Democratic senators on ballot in November go to great lengths to remind Pres Obama that voters hunger for signs of bipartisan cooperation; Republicans insist Democrats must move legislation to right (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Judson Phillips is a Tennessee lawyer, specializing in personal injury lawsuits, drunk-driving cases and men who get into trouble beating their wives. It was his idea to incorporate Tea Party Nation as a money-making venture and charge $349 to hear Sarah Palin talk about what's wrong with America over steak and lobster this weekend in Nashville.
docs.abstract: Sarah Palin wants to get in front of the same parade John Edwards wanted to lead, and the resemblance doesn't end there.

docs.lead_paragraph: For President Obama and Congressional Democrats groping for a new strategy on major health care legislation, one crucial question is whether the way forward is to the right or to the left - or would it perhaps be better to just stand still?

headline.main: To the Right? The Left? Tough Questions Now for Democrats

docs.abstract: Liberals, centrists and conservatives all think health care legislation is more likely to pass if it moves in their direction.
docs.snippet: Liberals, centrists and conservatives all think health care legislation is more likely to pass if it moves in their direction.

docs.lead_paragraph: Across the first thirteen months of the Obama era, Wisconsin's Paul Ryan, the ranking Republican on the House Budget Committee, has been one of the few conservative politicians offering detailed alternatives to the Democratic agenda. When Obama released his initial budget, Ryan responded by issuing a sweeping fiscal roadmap that envisioned bringing the U.S. budget back into balance across the next three decades. While many of his fellow Republicans were greeting Obama's health care push with Medicare demagoguery, Ryan was busy co-sponsoring (with Tom Coburn, among others) the "Patients' Choice Act," an imperfect but impressive alternative to the Democrats' approach. And now, with the release of Obama's second budget, which projects deficits as far as the eye can see, Ryan has updated his fiscal roadmap as well - and suddenly, people are paying attention to him.
docs.abstract: A Wisconsin Congressman's quest for fiscal solvency -- and a conservative welfare state.
docs.snippet: A Wisconsin Congressman's quest for fiscal solvency -- and a conservative welfare state.
